edge: Taare Zameen Par is a 2007 Indian Hindi-language psychological drama film that explores the life and imagination of Ishaan, an artistically gifted 8-year-old boy.
Ishaan is suspected to be dyslexic by the new art teacher Nikumbh in Taare Zameen Par.
Nikumbh is a new art teacher introduced in Taare Zameen Par.
Ishaan's poor academic performance leads his parents to send him to a boarding school in Taare Zameen Par.
Taare Zameen Par is a 2007 Indian Hindi-language psychological drama film.
Taare Zameen Par helps raise awareness about dyslexia.
Shankar–Ehsaan–Loy composed the score for Taare Zameen Par.

node_2: development process of taare zameen par
edge: The husband and wife team of Amole Gupte and Deepa Bhatia developed the story that eventually became Taare Zameen Par as a way of understanding why some children could not conform to a conventional educational system.
The husband and wife team of Amole Gupte and Deepa Bhatia
Bhatia and Gupte worked with dyslexic children from the Maharashtra Dyslexia Association to research and develop the screenplay.
Bhatia and Gupte worked with dyslexic children from Parents for a Better Curriculum for the Child (PACE) to research and develop the screenplay.
Dyslexia eventually became the central topic and theme of the film.

node_2: original inspiration for taare zameen par
edge: Bhatia's original inspiration was the childhood of Japanese filmmaker Akira Kurosawa, who did poorly in school.
Bhatia said in an interview with The Hindu that her original inspiration was the childhood of Japanese filmmaker Akira Kurosawa, who did poorly in school.
Bhatia and Gupte developed the story that eventually became Taare Zameen Par as a way of understanding why some children could not conform to a conventional educational system.
Bhatia and Gupte worked with dyslexic children to research and develop the screenplay.
Bhatia and Gupte carefully concealed the children's identities in the final version of the script.
Amole has written a brilliant and moving script for the film. Scriptwriter refers to an individual who writes scripts for films, plays or television programs.
During the entire pre-production phase, Amole served as the Creative Director of the film. A Creative Director is responsible for overseeing and guiding the creative vision of a project.
While shooting, Amole was present on set as a strong guiding force for the director. This signifies his role in providing support and direction to the director during the filmmaking process.
The director expresses gratitude towards Amole for entrusting him with something that is close to him. This demonstrates a trust-based relationship between the two individuals.
The task of creating music during pre-production was also handled by Amole, who served as the Creative Director. This highlights his involvement in multiple aspects of the film's production.

Aamir Khan admired Amole Gupte's abilities as an actor, writer, and painter before they first met in college. Three years before the film's release, Gupte brought Khan to the project as a producer and actor. However, after viewing the first week's dailies, Khan lost faith in Gupte's capability of translating what he had written on paper onto screen. This led to creative differences between the two, with Khan considering withdrawing his participation in the film. Gupte kept Khan on board by stepping down as director.
Khan acted as director for Taare Zameen Par, following Gupte's decision to step down due to creative differences. This was Khan's first experience in the dual role of actor and director.
Gupte remained on set during production, guiding and at times correcting Khan as he took over the role of director.

edge: With the working title no longer relevant, Khan, Gupte, and Bhatia discussed several alternatives, eventually deciding on Taare Zameen Par.

node_2: possible translations of this title include stars on the ground and like stars on earth.
edge: According to Khan:
The title Taare Zameen Par, which translates to 'stars on the ground', has a very positive connotation and celebrates the abilities of children.
The film Taare Zameen Par is about children, who are all special and wonderful, just like stars on earth.
Principal photography for the film Taare Zameen Par took place in India over five months.

Filmed in Mumbai using a permanent railway-station set. The train set piece's immobility was worked around by placing the camera on a moving trolley to create the illusion of a departing train.
To compensate for the 'absolutely petrified' Safary, most joint shots used a body double, though other portions integrated close-up shots of the actor.
The production team searched for a Mumbai school with an 'oppressive' feel to establish the 'heaviness of being in a metropolitan school'. The school chosen was St. Xavier's School.
The production crew moved from Ishaan's small house in Mysore Colony, Chembur to the 'vast, beautiful environs' of Panchgani.
Filming took place on weekends to minimise the background noise.
An early scene in which Ishaan was sent out of the classroom was filmed on the day of the Mumbai Marathon.
The production staff placed acrylic sheets invisible to the naked eye on the classroom windows to mask the sounds of nearby crowds and helicopters.

Production relied on stock footage for the brief scene of a bird feeding its babies. Khan carefully selected a clip to his liking, but learned three weeks before the film's release that the footage was not available in the proper format.

Because filming at New Era High School occurred during the winter holiday, those portraying Ishaan's classmates gave up their vacation to participate. A total of 1,500 children were used for wide-shots of the film's art-fair climax; medium shots only required 400 students.

Unorthodox methods to work around their rookie mistakes, such as speaking continuously in an attempt to 'bore the hell out of [them]' during a school assembly and filming them while Khan recited a tale for a later scene.

The film's title sequence, representing Ishaan's imagination, marked the first instance of claymation in a Bollywood film. Khan gave claymation artist Dhimant Vyas free rein over the various elements.

The '3 into 9' sequence, in which Ishaan delves into his imagination to solve a math problem, was originally conceived as a 3D animation. However, Khan scrapped the project and hired Vaibhav Kumaresh, who hand-drew the scene as a 2D animation.
Artist Samir Mondal composed Ishaan and Nikumbh's art-fair watercolor paintings. He held a workshop with schoolchildren, and incorporated elements from their artwork into Ishaan's.
The art department's designs for Ishaan's school notebooks disappointed Khan, who had familiarized himself with dyslexic writing. Using his left hand, Khan instead wrote it himself.
Gupte created the rest of Ishaan's artwork.
Assistant Art Director Veer Nanavati drew Ishaan's flipbook.

Taare Zameen Par was released worldwide on December 14, 2007, in countries such as Australia, Malaysia, New Zealand, and Fiji on December 20. This global debut followed revenue-sharing issues between the film's distributors and theatre owners that caused slight delays in India.

Within the first three days of its release, Taare Zameen Par grossed ₹150 million in India. This figure increased to ₹770 million after the Maharashtra government granted the film exemption from the entertainment tax.
To reach more audiences, Taare Zameen Par was later dubbed in Tamil and Telugu. Both versions were scheduled for release on September 12, 2008.
As of now, reports regarding the film's worldwide gross have conflicted, with sources citing $19.78 million, $21.52 million, $31.68 million, and $32.65 million.

The film received widespread critical acclaim upon release.
On the review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, 93% of 14 critics' reviews are positive for Taare Zameen Par.
On the review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, 93% of 14 critics' reviews are positive for Taare Zameen Par's critical acclaim.

Subhash K. Jha suggests that the film is 'a work of art, a water painting where the colors drip into our hearts' and holds back where it could easily resort to an extravagant display of drama and emotions.'
Subhash K. Jha argues that the true power of the film lies in its 'remarkable, rooted, rock-solid script which provides the landscape for such an emotionally engaging, heart-warming experience.'

Rajeev Masand stated that the film is 'a far cry from the formulaic masala flicks churned out by the Bollywood machine' and argued that Taare Zameen Par is 'an inspirational story that is as emotive as it is entertaining; this is a little twinkling star of a movie.'
Manish Gajjar stated that the film 'touches your heart and moves you deeply with its sterling performances'.

Aprajita Anil gave the film four stars and stated, 'Taare Zameen Par cannot be missed. Because it is different. Because it is delightful. Because it would make everyone think. Because it would help everyone grow.' Aprajita Anil also stated, 'And of course because the 'perfectionist' actor has shaped into a 'perfectionist'.'
Anurag Kashyap's statement after watching the movie Taare Zameen Par reflects a deeply emotional response, highlighting the movie's impact on him.
Anurag Kashyap's statement also suggests a similarity between his own experiences in college and the movie's plot, as he mentions being reminded of his hostel days.
The term dyslexia is a central concept in the movie Taare Zameen Par, as it focuses on the challenges faced by children with learning disabilities.
The statement 'the 'perfectionist' actor has shaped into a 'perfectionist' director' highlights the transformation of an actor, in this case likely referring to Aamir Khan, into a director.
The term 'gripping' is used to describe the performances in Taare Zameen Par as being particularly engaging and captivating.
In Jha's opinion, Nikumbh's lecture in the film was a source of criticism for being too preachy.
Jha found Ishaan's father's acting in the film to be overly dramatic.

edge: It was reported that the core plot of the movie was similar to the 1985 American movie Love, Mary.
Ishaan's portrayal in the movie 'Taare Zameen Par' showcases traits of dyslexic savant syndrome, which includes artistic talents that improve with support.
Ambar Chakravarty noted the general accuracy of Ishaan's dyslexia in his article 'Taare Zameen Par and dyslexic savants.'
Chakravarty was puzzled by Ishaan's trouble in simple arithmetic, which is a trait of dyscalculia rather than dyslexia.
Chakravarty deemed the growth of Ishaan's artistic talents after receiving help and support from Nikumbh as 'the most important (and joyous) neurocognitive phenomenon' of the film.
The improvement in Ishaan's artistic talents highlights cosmetic neurology, which is a major and therapeutically important issue in cognitive neuroscience and neuropsychology.

The authors believed the film raises serious questions on mental health perspectives and explores how threats and coercion are not capable of unearthing rich human potentialities deeply embedded in children, while teachers should instead map their strengths and weaknesses. The pair wrote that Khan 'dexterously drives home the precise point that our first priority ought to be getting to know the child before making any efforts to fill them with knowledge and abilities'. This highlights how the film depicts how 'threats and coercion are not capable of unearthing rich human potentialities deeply embedded in children' and suggests that teachers should instead map their strengths and weaknesses. Overall, the authors found a 'naive oversimplification' in the film and also felt that Khan 'dexterously drives home the precise point that our first priority ought to be getting to know the child before making any efforts to fill them with knowledge and abilities'. This implies that Khan's approach is more effective in unlocking the potential of children than the one that involves threats and coercion.

The authors believed that the film 'Stars on the Ground' blends modern professional knowledge with a humane approach in working with a dyslexic child. This suggests that the film incorporates up-to-date and evidence-based practices while also showing empathy and sensitivity towards children with learning disabilities.

The pair wrote that Khan 'dexterously drives home the precise point that our first priority ought to be getting to know the child before making any efforts to fill them with knowledge and abilities'. This highlights how the film depicts how 'threats and coercion are not capable of unearthing rich human potentialities deeply embedded in children' and suggests that teachers should instead map their strengths and weaknesses. The authors also believed that the film expands beyond disabilities and explores the 'present age where everyone is in a restless hurry'. This implies that the film addresses how modern society's fast-paced and competitive culture can hinder child development and learning.

edge: The authors felt that the film 'Stars on the Ground' raises serious questions on mental health perspectives and explores how threats and coercion are not capable of unearthing rich human potentialities deeply embedded in children, while teachers should instead map their strengths and weaknesses. The pair wrote that Khan 'dexterously drives home the precise point that our first priority ought to be getting to know the child before making any efforts to fill them with knowledge and abilities'. This highlights how the film depicts how 'threats and coercion are not capable of unearthing rich human potentialities deeply embedded in children' and suggests that teachers should instead map their strengths and weaknesses. The authors also believed that the film explores how we seem to be heading to a state of mass scale mindlessness even as children are being pushed to 'perform' and raises serious questions on mental health perspectives, implying that this culture of fast-paced living can lead to numbness towards the more profound aspects of life.

In the given context, 'learning disability' is a concept related to 'naive oversimplification'. The pair found a 'naive oversimplification' in the film, and with India 'only recently waking to recognizing the reality and tragedy of learning disability', they easily forgave this fault under artistic license.

The film has had a similarly positive response in Greater China, where the film was not officially released yet has a large online cult following due to Aamir Khan's popularity in the region after the success of 3 Idiots (2009).
The film is one of the highest-rated films on popular Chinese film site Douban, along with two other Aamir Khan films, 3 Idiots and Dangal (2016).
The film has been well received by Chinese audiences for how it tackles issues such as education and dyslexia.

Three days before Chandni Chowk to China hit theaters in the U.S. And India, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences announced its shortlist of nine films edging closer to a foreign-language nomination. India's submission, the powerful and moving Taare Zameen Par by Aamir Khan, didn't make the cut.
The film was made by Aamir Khan.

The Indian news media frequently compared Taare Zameen Par's nomination failure with the British drama film Slumdog Millionaire's multiple Academy Award nominations and wins. Film critic Rajeev Masand argued that it is difficult to compare the two films, but Slumdog Millionaire was being marketed in a way that Indian films such as Taare Zameen Par could not compete with.

Slumdog Millionaire actor Mahesh Manjrekar stated, "I'm sad that Aamir's Taare Zameen Par didn't make it to the final round of the Oscars."
